page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 110: Line 110:
Reports emerged of several major prisons across the country being attacked, and law and order rapidly deteriorated across most of Egypt.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html ''Al Jazeera English'' coverage of events].</ref> Criminal violence continued in Cairo as looters burnt out the Arkadia shopping mall. [[Egypt Air]] cancelled all internal and outbound flights;<ref name="aljazeera1" /><ref name="wilsherline.net.uk">[http://www.wilsherline.net.uk/ "Egypt Air cancels all flights"]</ref> an inbound Egypt Air flight from London to Cairo was diverted to [[Athens]] because of an alleged bomb threat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comparecarhire.co.uk/news/egyptair-jet-diverted-to-athens-after-bomb-scare-53824639.html|title=EgyptAir Jet Diverted to Athens after Bomb Scare |publisher=Comparecarhire.co.uk|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
Reports emerged of several major prisons across the country being attacked, and law and order rapidly deteriorated across most of Egypt.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html ''Al Jazeera English'' coverage of events].</ref> Criminal violence continued in Cairo as looters burnt out the Arkadia shopping mall. [[Egypt Air]] cancelled all internal and outbound flights;<ref name="aljazeera1" /><ref name="wilsherline.net.uk">[http://www.wilsherline.net.uk/ "Egypt Air cancels all flights"]</ref> an inbound Egypt Air flight from London to Cairo was diverted to [[Athens]] because of an alleged bomb threat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comparecarhire.co.uk/news/egyptair-jet-diverted-to-athens-after-bomb-scare-53824639.html|title=EgyptAir Jet Diverted to Athens after Bomb Scare |publisher=Comparecarhire.co.uk|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
â
Industrial strikes were also called in many cities, including Cairo.{{Which?|date=January 2011}}<!--from tv--> The Japanese firm [[Nissan]] had suspended production at its plant in Egypt to ensure employees' safety after anti-government protests, but the Korean owned [[Hyundai]]'s plant chose to continue working.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.just-auto.com/news/nissan-suspends-production-at-giza-plant_id108821.aspx|title=Egypt: Nissan Suspends Production at Giza Plant: Automotive News & Analysis|publisher=Just-auto.com|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
+
Industrial strikes were also called in many cities, including Cairo.<ref>http://www.thelondondailynews.com/lets-cheer-democracy-egypt-p-5046.html</ref> The Japanese firm [[Nissan]] had suspended production at its plant in Egypt to ensure employees' safety after anti-government protests, but the Korean owned [[Hyundai]]'s plant chose to continue working.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.just-auto.com/news/nissan-suspends-production-at-giza-plant_id108821.aspx|title=Egypt: Nissan Suspends Production at Giza Plant: Automotive News & Analysis|publisher=Just-auto.com|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
[[Zahi Hawass]], an internationally known [[archeologist]], was appointed by Mubarak to the newly created cabinet post of Minister of Antiquities during the cabinet shakeup on 31 January. Hawass said in a statement published on his personal blog that "the broken objects can all be restored, and we will begin the restoration process this week".<ref name="hawass-update">{{cite web|url=http://www.drhawass.com/blog/state-egyptian-antiquities-today-update|title=The State of Egyptian Antiquities Today: An Update|date=1 February 2011|work=Dr.hawass.com|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> In a ''[[New York Times]]'' interview he rejected comparisons with Iraq and Afghanistan and said that antiquities were being safeguarded.<ref name="Taylor">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02antiquities.html|title=Egyptian Official, Zahi Hawass, Says Antiquities Are Secure|last=Taylor|first=Kate|date=2 February 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Luis Ayala]], the secretary-general of the [[Socialist International]] said that the NDP was expelled because:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistinternational.org/images/dynamicImages/files/Letter%20NDP.pdf|title=To the General Secretary of the National Democratic Party, Egypt|publisher=Socialist International|accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
[[Zahi Hawass]], an internationally known [[archeologist]], was appointed by Mubarak to the newly created cabinet post of Minister of Antiquities during the cabinet shakeup on 31 January. Hawass said in a statement published on his personal blog that "the broken objects can all be restored, and we will begin the restoration process this week".<ref name="hawass-update">{{cite web|url=http://www.drhawass.com/blog/state-egyptian-antiquities-today-update|title=The State of Egyptian Antiquities Today: An Update|date=1 February 2011|work=Dr.hawass.com|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> In a ''[[New York Times]]'' interview he rejected comparisons with Iraq and Afghanistan and said that antiquities were being safeguarded.<ref name="Taylor">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02antiquities.html|title=Egyptian Official, Zahi Hawass, Says Antiquities Are Secure|last=Taylor|first=Kate|date=2 February 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Luis Ayala]], the secretary-general of the [[Socialist International]] said that the NDP was expelled because:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistinternational.org/images/dynamicImages/files/Letter%20NDP.pdf|title=To the General Secretary of the National Democratic Party, Egypt|publisher=Socialist International|accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
